awd_titl_txt: Partition of Solute Atoms among Sublattices in Intermetallic Compounds
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract:

Many technological materials are compounds with ordered crystal structures.  Mechanical strength and other properties have frequently been improved by dissolving solute atoms into the compound.  This project will explore how solute atoms partition between sublattices of the host elements.  The ways in which solutes partition may have important and unrecognized influences over materials properties.  However, the partition, that is, the distribution of solute atoms on the two sublattices, has been difficult to measure.  An experimental hyperfine interaction method similar to that used in magnetic resonance imaging will be employed that can measure the distribution accurately.  The principal goal is to determine how the precise composition of the host compound, the amount of dissolved solute, and temperature all affect the partition.  Knowledge gained should help predict how solutes partition for other combinations of host compounds and solutes and thereby advance the general field of solutions in solids.   Other impacts  include education and training of undergraduate and graduate students and dissemination of research findings by all research participants to the broader public through participation in scientific meetings, seminars, and publications.  


Technical Abstract:

The goal of this project is to determine how solute atoms partition among different sites in a compound.  Considering an ordered binary compound AB2, do solute atoms distribute on one or both sublattices?  Investigations will be carried out to determine how the partition varies with deviation from a stoichiometric A:B composition ratio, with the mole fraction of solute, and with temperature.  A thematic hypothesis to be explored is that the sum of mole fractions of solutes and antisite atoms is constrained by phase boundaries and the solubility.  The partition of solute atoms has heretofore been difficult to measure.  Lattice locations of In-probe atoms will be resolved using the nuclear method perturbed angular correlation of gamma rays (PAC).  Studies will focus on GdAl2.   Phase boundaries and solubility limits will be precisely measured.  Solute partition will also be studied in hosts for which the phase field extends to both sides of the stoichiometric composition, leading to differing types of structural point defects. Properties of many functional and structural materials are improved by addition of 1 at.% of solute.  The ways in which solutes are partitioned may have important influences over material properties that have not been recognized up until now.  The project is expected to comprehensively advance understanding of solute partition.  Broader impacts include advanced education and training of students in solid-state physics, nuclear laboratory methods, and data analysis.   Research findings are to be disseminated by all research participants to the broader public through participation in local and national scientific meetings, seminars, and publications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project contributed to an improved understanding of the theory of solutions in solids.   Consider an ordered binary compound having the ideal structure A2B.  Host-elements A and B occupy different sublattices and their lattice sites have different surroundings.  We are interested in solid-phases in which solute atoms of a third element, C, occupy sites on both sublattices, taking the place of, say, 1% of the host atoms.  Due to differences in bonding of atom C with its neighbors on sites A or B, there will in general be a difference in the energy of atom C on site A or site B.  When temperature is increased, atoms can jumps to other sites via diffusion (atom motion).  Thus, the numbers of C-atoms on sites A and B can change.  Using an experimental technique like PAC (similar to NMR), one can make measurements of the ratio of fractions of C-atoms on A and B sublattices as a function of temperature.  If the concentration, or mole-fraction of solute C-atoms is very low, the temperature-dependence of the ratio can be analysed to determine the limiting value DE*, which represents the difference in site-energies of the solute on the two sites in the low-concentration limit.

 

Extensive measurements have been made in our group on the phase Al2Gd with In (indium) solutes.  While measurements with extremely dilute amounts of In solutes exhibited an energy difference DE*= 0.343 eV between In-solutes on the two sublattices, later measurements made in the group with greater mole-fractions of C-atoms led to smaller values  DE.  Indeed, measurements showed that the apparent value of DE, called DE, decreased linearly to zero when the solute mole-fraction increased to 0.5 at.%.   We call empirical values of DE the transfer-enthalpy of a solute atom between the two sublattices. 

 

An important outcome of this project was to identify the origin of the apparent decrease in DE.  It is a natural consequence of the dependence of the “free energy” of the solute atoms on the two sublattices on the mole-fraction of solute.  Free-energy includes the actual energy of the solute-atom connected with bonding and a contribution due to the configurational entropy of solute atoms; very roughly, how many different ways they can fit onto the two sublattices.  If there are only a few solute atoms and there is a vast number of sublattice sites that solutes can occupy, the configurational entropy is not important.  However, if the number of solute atoms is close to the solubility limit, beyond which no further solute atoms can be dissolved, then there are very few different ways in which the solute atoms can fit on the sublattice, the free-energy becomes small, and the apparent value of DE is close to zero.  To sum up, the apparent value of DE decreases with increasing mole-fraction of solute and becomes zero at the solubility limit, offering a novel method for measuring it.   In effect, close to the solubility limit the solutes become “jammed” and unable to jump between the sublattices.

 

Phase boundaries of Al2Gd without dissolved solute. 

 In general, the composition of ordered compounds such as Al2Gd has “wiggle room” allowing the composition to deviate by small amounts from the stoichiometric composition of 33.33 at.%Gd.  Deviations are made possible by the presence of intrinsic point defects.  For example, one can make samples of Al2Gd that are slightly Al-rich if some Al-atoms occupy sites normally occupied by Gd-atoms and replace them.  But this adds to the energy of the compound and one can only deviate by a small amount before the excess Al starts to make another, more Al-richer phase. 

 Skipping some details, experiments showed that the limiting composition of Al-rich Al2Gd was about 33.1 at.% Gd, only removed a little bit from stoichiometry.  With less certainty, the Gd-rich limiting composition is probably of order 33.5 at.%Gd.

 Thus, one can deviate from the stoichiometric composition by a 0.1-0.2 at.% addition of Al or Gd, or by a 0.5 at.% addition of In-solute.  

 

Transfer enthalpies of In in a series of phases of composition Al2R.  

 Recall that the transfer-enthalpy for dilute In solutes represents the enthalpy-difference between solutes on R- or Al-sites.  Here, R represents a rare-earth element and experiments were carried out for R= La, Ce, Nd, Sm, Dy, Gd, Ho, Tm.  It was 0.343 eV for Al2Gd.   The transfer enthalpy was found to increase monotonically from about 0.05 eV for Al2La to 0.343 eV for Al2Gd.
